page.title: Reflect before you start
page.contents:
This lesson is called The Principle of Relativity, because it concerns how different observers moving relative to each other may measure different properties of physical systems, but experiments they do will, nevertheless, agree on what physical laws are being obeyed.  It will cover:

  • Inertial and non-inertial reference frames
  • What quantities do different observers measure to be different when they both observe the same physical process?
  • The Principle of Relativity
  • Using the Principle of Relativity to solve collision problems

Before you start to look at any complicated content, whether it is a textbook, a set of video lectures, a web page, whatever, it is a good idea to prepare to learn by doing a bit of reflection.  To develop the habit it is good to write some reflections.  In the space below write three things (sentences, point form, whatever you want) about what you are about to learn.  Here are some things you might write about below:

  • List things that you think you might learn about in the lesson (in more detail than was given in the list above).
  • List things that you already know about the topics of this lesson.
  • List things that you have heard about these topics, but don't understand.

page.title: Sam non-inertial
page.contents:
A low-friction cart moves left at a constant 4 m/s relative to the Earth frame as shown.  Trogdor and his majestic yellow ruler move right at a constant 2 m/s relative to the Earth Frame.  Sam, at this instant is also moving at 2 m/s to the right relative to the Earth frame but he is speeding up at a rate of 3 m/s2. 

Which of the following is true?

answer.answer_text: Trogdor measures the cart's momentum to be constant but Sam measures it as changing.
Sam and Trogdor agree that the cart's momentum is constant.
answer.response: No. Since Sam's velocity relative to the Earth is changing but the cart's is staying constant relative to the Earth the cart's velocity relative to Sam is changing. So Sam measures it to be accelerating. This means that according to Sam the cart's momentum is changing.

answer.answer_text: Sam and Trogdor both measure the cart's momentum to be changing.
answer.response: No. Trogdor is in an inertial frame and the cart is moving at constant velocity relative to the Earth. So according to Trogdor the cart's momentum is constant.

answer.answer_text: Sam measures the cart's momentum to be constant but Trogdor measures it as changing.
answer.response: No, you've got it backwards. The relative velocity between the cart and Trogdor is constant, but the relative velocity between Sam and the cart is changing since Sam is accelerating relative to the Earth.

page.title: Which are inertial frames?
page.contents:
Trogdor and his majestic yellow ruler move to the right at a constant 2 m/s.  A low friction cart moves left at a constant 4 m/s.  Sam, on his super-modern bike, moves right.  At the moment he is going 2 m/s but he is speeding up at a rate of 3 m/s.

Which reference frames are inertial?

answer.answer_text: Yes.  Constant velocity frames are inertial.  Accelerating frames are non-inertial.
No.  Frames that move at constant velocity are inertial.  Accelerating frames are non-inertial.

page.title: You and Sam observing collision - momentum
page.contents:
Olaf has finally caught up with the Human Torch to give him a big hug.  Their cart's A and B are moving at the velocities shown in the diagram before they collide.  The cart's collide and bounce off of each other elastically.  You and Sam are watching this process and making careful measurements.  You are stationary on the ground and Sam is riding by on his bicycle at constant velocity.  The system is the two carts, Olaf and the Human Torch.

Which of the following is true?

answer.answer_text: You and Sam agree about the changes of momentum of the carts and about whether the momentum of the system was conserved.
answer.response: Yes. You agree on the delta-v of objects and that is all you need to measure to know about the changes in momentum.

answer.answer_text: You and Sam disagree about the changes of momentum of the individual carts but you agree about whether the system's momentum was conserved.
answer.response: No. You agree on the delta-v of objects and that is all you need to measure to know about the changes in momentum.

answer.answer_text: You and Sam agree about the changes of momentum of the individual carts but you disagree about whether the system's momentum was conserved.
answer.response: No. Does that make sense? The change in the momentum of the system would just be the sum of the changes of momentum of the carts. So if you agree on the changes of momentum of each cart how could you disagree on the change of momentum of the whole system?

answer.answer_text: You and Sam disagree about the changes of momentum of the individual carts and you disagree about whether the system's momentum was conserved.
answer.response: No. You agree on the delta-v of objects and that is all you need to measure to know about the changes in momentum.

page.title: Objects changing direction
page.contents: A collision occurs and an observer in the Earth frame sees both objects in the collision change their directions of motion.  What do other observers in different inertial frames see?

answer.answer_text: Some will see both objects changing direction, but others will not. However they all agree on the \( \Delta \vec{v} \) vectors of the objects.
Because they all measure the same \( \Delta \vec{v} \) vectors for the objects, every observer agrees about whether the objects have changed direction.
answer.response: No. Remember that the sign of a Delta v component does not tell you whether an object has changed direction. For example, an object going to the right at 3 m/s then to the left at 2 m/s has the same Delta v as an object going to the right at 8 m/s and then continuing to the right at 3 m/s.

answer.answer_text: Observers in different frames measure different velocities for the objects and so they disagree about the \( \Delta \vec{v} \) vectors. However, since they agree on relative velocities they all see both objects change direction.
answer.response: No. First of all they agree on all Delta v vectors. Second of all, the relative velocities doesn't tell you whether the objects have changed direction. It only tells you how they have changed direction *relative to each other*.

answer.answer_text: All observers will agree that both objects changed direction. But they will disagree about the values of the \( \Delta \vec{v} \) vectors for the objects.
answer.response: No. First of all they agree on all Delta v vectors. Second of all, knowing the Delta v vectors alone doesn't tell you whether the objects have changed direction. The observers will disagree about whether the objects have changed direction.

page.title: Is center of mass velocity constant?
page.contents:
A collisions occurs between two cars.  Both cars had their brakes applied before during and after the collision.  The system is just the two cars.  Was the center of mass velocity of the system constant during this collision?  Hint: remember that:

$$\vec{v}_{AZ} = \frac{\vec{p}_{ASys}}{m_{Sys}}$$

answer.answer_text: Yes. We’ve seen that center of mass velocity is always constant.
answer.response: Think about this. If you kick an object across the floor, friction will eventually bring it to rest. If the system is just the object then the center of mass is at the center of mass of the one object. Since the object slows down, the center of mass velocity is clearly not constant. So apparently the center of mass velocity is not *always* constant.

answer.answer_text: No. The system is not isolated.
answer.response: Yes. The system momentum is not constant because of external interactions, and so the center of mass velocity is not constant.

answer.answer_text: It depends on the inertias of cars.
answer.response: Really? Should physical laws depend on what we try to apply them to, or should they be universal?

page.title: Comparing views of coin toss
page.contents:
You toss a coin up in the air and then catch it.  Your friend standing beside you measures the time between the coin leaving your hand and the catch.

A person in a nearby building is in a high speed elevator with glass walls and so they can see the coin toss as well. The elevator is going up fast.  Is the time interval recorded by this person between the coin leaving your hand longer, shorter or the same as the time interval measured by your friend?

(In case you think it matters - while the elevator is fast, it is much, much, much, much, much, much, much slower than the speed of light...)

answer.answer_text: The time interval is the same.
answer.response:
Yes. That's what the Galilean transformation equations tell us.
This is slightly wrong, but for the sorts of speeds involved here you would need clocks much more precise than we have ever built to observe the difference in measured time intervals. So it is reasonable to use the Galilean transformation.

answer.answer_text: Because the elevator is going up the observer in the elevator observes a smaller initial upward speed for the coin. So according to them the time interval is shorter.
answer.response: No, they also see your hand going down. The lower upward speed is exactly compensated for by the fact that according to them the coin had to fall back down farther to get to your hand. But that is an unnecessarily complicated way of looking at it. We are talking about the time interval between two events (the coin leaving your hand and the coin arriving back at your hand). The Galilean transform equations tell us that all observers measure the same time intervals between events.

answer.answer_text: Because the elevator is going up the observer in the elevator observes your hand to be going down, which means the coin has farther to fall back down to get to your hand. So according to them the time interval is longer.
answer.response: No, they also see a smaller initial upward speed for the coin. The lower upward speed is exactly compensated for by the fact that according to them the coin had to fall back down farther to get to your hand. But that is an unnecessarily complicated way of looking at it. We are talking about the time interval between two events (the coin leaving your hand and the coin arriving back at your hand). The Galilean transform equations tell us that all observers measure the same time intervals between events.

page.title: You and Sam observing collision - energy
page.contents:
Olaf has finally caught up with the Human Torch to give him a big hug.  Their cart's A and B are moving at the velocities shown in the diagram before they collide.  The cart's collide and bounce off of each other elastically.  You and Sam are watching this process and making careful measurements.  You are stationary on the ground and Sam is riding by on his bicycle at constant velocity.  The system is the two carts, Olaf and the Human Torch.

Which of the following is true?

answer.answer_text: You and Sam agree that the change of kinetic energy during the collision was zero. But you disagree about how much the kinetic energy of each cart has changed.
You and Sam agree that the change of kinetic energy during the collision was zero and you agree about how much the kinetic energy of each cart has changed.
answer.response: No. Both carts are going faster according to Sam, but kinetic energy is a nonlinear function of speed. You will agree about the delta-v of each cart, but because of the non-linear nature of kinetic energy Sam will see a larger change of kinetic energy.

answer.answer_text: According to you the system's kinetic energy did not change. But according to Sam it did change. So you disagree about whether the collision was elastic.
answer.response: No. If you disagreed about the change in kinetic energy of the system then you would also have to disagree about a state change either in the system or in the environment. Does it make sense (for example) that according to one of you the bumper on one of the carts got bent but the other of you could not observe this?

answer.answer_text: You agree about the changes in kinetic energy of each cart but you disagree about the change of kinetic energy of the system.
answer.response: No. Does that make sense? The change of the system's kinetic energy would just be sum of the changes of the kinetic energy of each cart. So if you agreed on the change of K of each cart then you would have to agree on the change of K for the system.

answer.answer_text: You and Sam don't agree about the changes of kinetic energy of either cart, and you don't agree about the change of kinetic energy of the system.
answer.response: No. If you disagreed about the change in kinetic energy of the system then you would also have to disagree about a state change either in the system or in the environment. Does it make sense (for example) that according to one of you the bumper on one of the carts got bent but the other of you could not observe this?
